embeds.title: Kindle
embeds.description:
Basic Skill / 1 :energy_hexa: / The Hexaghost / Downfall

If **Ignite)** the current Ghostflame​~~-  is not Ignited, **Ignite** it -~~ .

messages.content: 🚨 HEXAGHOST STARTER CARD ALERT 🚨
*hexa floor 0 upgrade discussion time!*
*FIGHT FIGHT FIGHT FIGHT*
fuck this card
i remove this card at first opportunity

this card does what it was intended to do
I like it, but it's a much better fifth upgrade than first
this single card throws your starter deck out of balance for ghost wheel AND is worse than a strike damage-wise
one card of imbalance is worth working around
things are heating up in the hexatoast fandom
as with all things earlygame hexaghost, I diagnose you all with skill issue
knowing when to play this card is all you need to make it fucking awesome
double triggers, upgrade to repeatable ignition, carries your power ghostflame until you get a power (and even then can often be useful when that power doesn't show up when you need it)
it's double ignition/bolstering igniter
does what it's meant to do
doesn't need upgrade much
you take that when you have lots of intensity sometimes

Okay so Kindle.
6 Soulburn, 12 damage, 9 Block and 1 Strength.
Or.... 48 damage and 4 Intensity.
This card is the only way in the starter deck to Ignite the Bolstering Ghostflame. It's also one of two ways in Hexaghost's entire draft to renewably ignite the Bolstering Ghostflame while on it, the other being <Flare Flick>. I just want to point out that 9 Block and 1 Strength for 1 Energy is a lot in the early game. That's a good portion of Block that isn't lowered by Lagavulin's debuffs.
Also, you really can't ignore that it's one of the four sources of Double Ignition in the entire draft. The others being the aforementioned Flare Flick, but there's also <Haunting Echo>, <Catch Up>, and <Instant Inferno>. Catch Up also requires a bit more movement to properly use. Haunting Echo is a great card, but unlike Kindle, it can't ignite the Bolstering Ghostflame just by itself. Flare Flick is a strong card for sure, but it also costs 2 and Hexa thrives on 1 and 0 cost cards to make the most of out each draw to convert them into Ghostflame tokens. Instant Inferno also exhausts, so it isn't a permanent scaling solution.
The best way to use this card is to have a lot of draw so you can use it to either save 1 energy on a Ghostflame, ignite the Bolstering Ghostflame, or to Double Ignite the Inferno Ghostflame. Of course, there's also Runic Pyramid, without a doubt the best boss relic for Hexa, which near 100% guarentees scaling off of the Inferno and consistency for the Bolstering Ghostflame, as well as all other Ghostflames forever.
The upgrade on this card isn't great until you have powers <Empowered Flame> or relics <Mark of the Ether> <Teakwood Match> that benefit from it, or you have enough intensity that using this card to reignite Kindle after having played a power that turn blocks for a substantial amount.

**Retain**.
Apply 12 (21) **Soulburn** :p_soulburn:.
Switch to and **Ignite** the Inferno Ghostflame. **Exhaust**.

embeds.description:

Replaces Spirit Brand.
Whenever you Ignite a Ghostflame , gain 4 **Block** :p_block:.

embeds.title: Sneaky Teakwood Match
embeds.description:
Rare Relic / The Hexaghost / Downfall

The first time you **Ignite** each turn, you can choose whether to **Advance** or **Retract.**
*-# Lights on any surface!*

messages.content:
Double Ignition on the Crushing and Inferno Ghostflames existing somewhat invalidates this as a floor 0 upgrade, since it only adds additional value to the Searing Ghostflames and Bolstering Ghostflame, and you don't have a power card in your starter deck to justify the upgrade for the sake of the Bolstering Ghostflame.
Now, about scaling off of the Inferno.
It's not anywhere near as fast as Infernal Form or some of the Ethereal strategies, but it is consistent and can be done by any deck because you start with Kindle. It's usually how you beat your Act 1 hero, especially considering that it boosts Soulburn application from your Searing Ghostflames, which will ignore whatever the act 1 hero is blocking for, which is especially important for Watcher 1, Hermit 1, and Ironclad 1.
If I'm trying to scale off of the Inferno, I'm going to put heavy value on Advance, any and all draw, 0 Costs, any method of Retain for consistency (especially Runic Pyramid), Cheap forms of Block so I can keep going around the Wheel as fast as possible, like Afterlife cards to benefit from my draw. I also want Energy to continue the combo as much as possible, usually <Time Warp>. Kindle ends up being pivotal in these fast, Inferno scaling decks because it is renewable and is already inside of the deck, meaning I don't have to add many cards to the deck, including power cards.
Now, every 4 points of Intensity is another 48 damage off of your Double Ignited Inferno. This is a lot, but not enough to win on its own in Act 3 and 4 if you're doing it every 6 turns. Don't do it every 6 turns. Try to do it every 3 turns.

embeds.title: Time Warp
embeds.description:
Rare Attack / 0 :energy_hexa: / The Hexaghost / Downfall

Deal 5 (7) damage.
Whenever you Advance or Retract, return this from the discard pile.

messages.content:
You want a thin deck after you're done with your Afterlife cards so you can redraw all of your 0 cost cards, convert them into tokens, Advance, and keep doing it, then Double Ignite the Inferno with Kindle. Double Igniting the other Ghostflames is nice, but should be considered a bonus rather than a requirement for your scaling and damage. Against Neow and the Corrupt Heart, you basically want to be speedrunning the Wheel so you have to deal with Regen 50 and the Heart's Strength Up as little as possible.
Outside of Inferno Scaling, if you're using Infernal Form (or Ethereal), it's not a requirement but is still very helpful frontloaded damage. Just don't try to force it like on an Inferno Scaling deck.

i was already typing when the hexaghost guide got dropped here so i'm gonna finish the thought then i'll read it

i know when the right time to use the card is. the problem is that unless you're using it for bolstering or inferno, it does a strike's worth of damage. and that's not accounting for:
* being on searing ghostflame and being able to proc it with attacks anyway
* being on searing, meaning the 6 damage is _soulburn_
* being on searing, and only having 1 strike in hand, often thanks to this card's existence
* being on crushing, but double casting crushing is the same damage as playing 2 skills + a strike
* being on searing OR crushing ghostflame, because the damage is randomly assigned
bro I said I liked it
I gotta agree with carbon I think you have skill issue, or rather evaluation issue
ever since sear was made into an attack, the RNG sank like a rock
that was a very helpful change, yes
Getting bricked on soulburn turn 1 is like drawing defend x5 nuet bane turn 1 as silent against jaw worm
and you can literally only say womp womp at that situation
with hexa, you just want to be applying soulburn t1 for act 1
just focus on adding decent attacks and replacing your defends with afterlife cards for those first 10 floors
make relevant pivots as you beat your first elite, enter your first shop, and find your early rare card
also, that wasn't taken from the guide, I just wrote it off the cuff
damn

Out of all of the difficulties I have with Hexaghost, Kindle was never one of them. Heck, Kindle has saved me more often than not. The added strength from Bolstering Ghostflame early on, for example. Kindle is a really good card for a starting card, and I don't understand the vitriol against it.
it's just evab's dislike
I don't know when the last winning hexa run without a kindle+ I had was

One other point to add to blue's posts is that kindle in the starting deck is also very helpful to get soulburn going on turn 1, and let you keep going and have momentum to move around the wheel. It helps fill in the gaps on turns where you can't quite ignite the current ghost flame, letting you get it for 1 energy instead, and allowing you to get some value, and continue progressing towards the other parts of the wheel, which contain very nice rewards like bolstering and inferno. If you draw no attacks turn 1, but you do have kindle, you can just cast it and that ensures that you get soulburn going for the earliest possible detonation (start of enemies turn 3, before they get to act). Admittedly, yes that soulburn goes on a random target, which could cause real issues in multi-enemy fights, but that's always true of searing ghostflames regardless of how you ignite them (barring the potion that makes them apply to all enemies). Having that little insurance policy against bad draws preventing wheel progression is really nice in the starting deck.

The more major role of the card is for double ignition, which can be underwhelming at first, but tends to get much more valuable as you start picking up sources of intensity/advance. You want to be able to have enough ability to move around the wheel to double ignite the most rewarding ghostflames. Even a small amount of intensity makes the flames start dealing a much more respectable amount of damage. Double igniting the inferno ghostflame closes out most fights pretty definitively, or gives you enough intensity to help you clean them up in short order. However, it's usually difficult to make act 1 fights last long enough/advance often enough to get that benefit. It tends to become more relevant as you start fighting enemies with more health later in the run, usually in act 3, but also against most (all?) bosses.

The upgrade is usually not super necessary in my opinion until later in the run, when you are better at reaching a fully prepared inferno ghostflame, and when you have plenty of powers to have a better shot at double igniting the bolstering. Having intensity access also makes double ignition much rewarding, so that is another reason to look into upgrading this, and it can even sometimes be used to ignite a flame 3 times in one turn once upgraded if you also have other cards like flare flick or haunting echo. The extra damage from sear is just too important for act 1, and the upside of upgrading this is just too niche within the starter deck for it to be a priority for me in act 1. Very strong with pyramid to ensure extra ignitions of the strongest ghostflames, especially when upgraded.
